abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Command Water
            Management Project for Pakistan was marginally satisfactory.
            The project achieved most of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            likely, and both the Bank and Borrower acted satisfactorily.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            while designing projects for canal command area development,
            institutional constraints should be carefully diagnosed, and
            resources and activities focused on achieving declared
            objectives. Second, a project aimed at raising agricultural
            production must delineate a structured role for agricultural
            extension services. Third, integrated management of
            irrigated agriculture needs a radical reorientation away
            from compartmentalized line agency thinking. Fourth,
            expatriate technical assistance must be closely integrated
            into the objectives and operations of the project. Lastly,
            water scheduling intervention promoted by expatriate experts
            must take into account that the Indus Canal System is water
            scarce by design, and farmers tend to maximize income per
            unit of water by expanding crop area rather than applying
            optimum amounts of water to crops.
